choices.C: Quarantined files are never deleted from the host

questions.question_text: How long are quarantined files stored on the host?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct. "90 days for cloud" 30 days for host.

Selected Answer: B

choices.C: The "Bulk Domains" search will show IP address and port information for any associated connections
choices.D: You should only pivot to the "Bulk Domains" search tool after completing an investigation
choices.A: It will show a list of computers and process that performed a lookup of any of the domains in your search
choices.B: The "Bulk Domains" search will allow you to blocklist your queried domains

questions.question_text: Which statement is TRUE regarding the "Bulk Domains" search?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

A. It will show a list of computers and process that performed a lookup of any of the domains in your search

Selected Answer: A
I previously provided the correct answer and explanation for this question. Here it is again:

The correct statement regarding the "Bulk Domains" search is:

A. It will show a list of computers and processes that performed a lookup of any of the domains in your search.

Selected Answer: A
It´s, when you using Bulk Domain tool, you can see only the host and process. But can´t see the IP Adress. So is A the correct

questions.question_text:
How are processes on the same plane ordered (bottom ‘VMTOOLSD.EXE’ to top ‘CMD.EXE’)?
//IMG//

choices.C: Time started (Ascending, most recent on top)
choices.B: Time started (Descending, most recent on bottom)

discussion.content: Validation in doc the question, help?

Selected Answer: C
On the old UI its C. New UI the answer would be B. Verified both on the same detection.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct, checked in the UI

C. Time started (Ascending, most recent on top)

discussion.content: B is correct, Ignore "wildbandana"

questions.question_text: What does pivoting to an Event Search from a detection do?

choices.D: It allows you to input an event type, such as DNS Request or ASEP write, and search for those events within the detection
choices.C: It takes you to a Process Timeline for that detection so you can see all related events
choices.B: It takes you to the raw Insight event data and provides you with a number of Event Actions
choices.A: It gives you the ability to search for similar events on other endpoints quickly

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer agree with B

Selected Answer: B
Agreed with sbag0024. The correct answer is 'B'. When investigating a detection, there will be a magnifying glass icon. Hovering and selecting 'Event Search' will open the Splunk equivalent search engine, exposing all of the raw data from the 'aid' and 'treeIdDecimal'.

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B. When you click on Full Detection data and then the 3 dots, you can pivot to Event Seach where you land on the raw data info where you can select "Event Actions" which there are a number of them to select. Going with B

Selected Answer: D
right one is D
